div1.head: Report: A Resume of the Anti-malarial Operations at Cristobal-Colon from 1917 to 1922, Inclusive, by J.L. Byrd, 1922
div1.p:
A RESUME OF THE ANTI-MALARIAL OPERATIONS
At Cristobal-Colon
From 1917 to 1922, inclusive.*
By
Dr. J. L. Byrd, Health Officer, Cristobal - Colon.

Cristobal-Colon has a population of 37,500, and is located on
Manzanillo Island near the Atlantic entrance of the Panama Canal. The
island was once a tidal swamp which is now filled in great part. This
was once widely known as one of the most unhealthy ports of the world,
yellow fever being rife until 1905, when it was eradicated by General
Gorgas and his co-workers. Malaria was very prevalent in Colon until
1920. The following table gives the number of cases of malaria report-
ed among the employees of the Panama Canal and the Panama Railroad in
Cristobal-Colon, from 1916 to 1922, inclusive:

In 1917 the anti-malaria work had been extended only about
one-half mile from the inhabited sections. This limited area was
thoroughly sanitated; all vegetation was kept closely trimmed; swampy
areas were either filled or carefully drained, and all drains were oiled
regularly every seven days. As a result, anopheles breeding was elinin-
(*) Read before the Medical Association of the
Isthmian Canal Zone, May 18, 1923.
2
ated within the area which included all of Manzanillo Island and a part
of what is now known as the Mt. Hope District. Nevertheless, the malarial
rate continued to remain very high in spite of the fact that no anopheles
were breeding within a radius of one-half to three-quarters of a mile of
the city.

Extensive swamps surround the city on three sides. On investiga-
tion, these were found to be breeding anopheles in countless numbers, and as
this breeding was occurring only one-half mile from the inhabited sections,
and as the adult mosquito catch in such sections was very high with a cor-
responding high malarial rate, it became necessary to control mosquito
breeding in these swamps. During 1917-1918 extensive drainage systems
were installed in them and anopheles breeding was controlled for a distance
of approximately one mile from the city. As a result, the malarial rate
for 1918 was lower than ever before, only 53 cases among the employees being
reported in Cristobal-Colon during the entire year, as compared with 148
cases for 1917.

In 1917, 1918, and 1919, great swarms of mosquitoes, largely
anophelines, appeared on the screens at Colon Hospital and the Hotel Wash-
ington. The swarms came regularly every year about two weeks after the
beginning of the rainy season and would continue for about three months.
The mosquitoes were so numerous that it was necessary to detail a laborer
for the purpose of killing them with larvacide applied with a knapsack
sprayer. The older sanitary inspectors stated that these swarms had ap-
peared every year since 1905.

This was at first very difficult to explain. Colon Hospital
is located on the extreme northern end of Manzanillo Island. The entire
area for a distance of over one mile from the hospital is thoroughly sani-
tated, and all anopheles breeding eliminated therefrom. The nearest
anopheles breeding area to Colon Hospital was located directly across Man-
zanillo Bay, a distance of approximately one mile and three quarters from,
and to the leeward of, the hospital. Many night observations were made
along Colon Beach and from boats anchored in the bay, and it was definitely
proven that the swarms of anophelines on the hospital and hotel screens were
coming from the Margarita swamps which begin one mile and three quarters
east and across Manzanillo Bay from the hospital. The bay is one mile wide.
The evidence of these long flights of anophelines was only accepted after
repeated observations and catches, since in view of the fact that prior to
1915 the concensus of opinion among sanitarians was that the anopheles
mosquito was not a strong flier and as a general rule did not travel over
200 yards from the breeding area. General Gorgas states (“Sanitation in
Panama”, page 182):

“all brush and undergrowth were cleared within
200 yards of houses and villages and the grounds
carefully drained within this area.”

However, on page 202 of the same book the author records a flight of
anopheles at Gatun of over one mile. Evidently this was considered at
that time as very unusual. The many flight observations made about Cris-
tobal-Colon during the past five years clearly show that long flights of
4
albimanus tarsimaculata anopheles are not unusual, it being found that
they will fly against an eight mile breeze for a distance of over two
miles. Margarita swamp was drained by sea-level canals during 1920-21,
and Colon Hospital has not been visited by these swarms of mosquitoes since
this work was well begun, although there have been several relatively small
Flights since that time. Apparently these are from swamps located more
than two miles from the hospital.

On May 2, 1919, all the colored workers at the Cristobal docks
and the coaling station walked out on strike. They were immediately re-
placed by native labor which was recruited from the interior, i. e.,
unsanitated sections of the Republic of Panama. It has been estimated
that over 80 percent of these laborers harbored the plasmodium malariae
in their blood, either as chronic malaria or as carriers. About 2,000
of them were brought to Cristobal-Colon during the strike and many of them
developed acute malaria within a week after their arrival in the city.
During June, July, and August, the labor camp, known as Camp Bierd, was
visited by the usual large flights of anopheles mosquitoes from Telfer's
Island swamps and the swamps near the Arcia dairy, a distance of one to two
miles from the camp. The chart of the number of adult anopheles mosquitoes
caught in quarters, shows that there were no more anopheles mosquitoes at
Camp Bierd in 1919 than in former years, and that the flights were about as
usual. However, the presence of the large number of natives greatly in-
creased the plasmodium index in the camp. Many of the natives had never
been in a hospital; they were superstitious and had a dreadful fear of all
5
hospitals, and as a result many of them would remain sick in camp for
several days and would not seek medical attention. The Jamaican jani-
tors first reported several sick men in camp and on investigation it was
found that they were suffering from malaria. They had to be forced in-
to the hospitals under guard, but many of the mild cases evaded the camp
inspections. The result of this unusual condition was an epidemic of
malaria in Camp Bierd and vicinity. As many as 21 cases were reported
in a single week from this locality. In order to control this outbreak
the following measures were taken:
1. Drainage work was immediately begun in the anopheles
breeding areas on Telfer's Island and vicinity.
2. Splenic Index: A blood smear and splenic examina-
tion was made on every person living in Camp Bierd, and
those found with large spleens, or showing signs or symptoms
of clinical malaria, were hospitalized.
3. Quinine sterilization and immunization: Every person
living in Camp Bierd was given ten grains of quinine in
liquid form every day for three months.
4. A dusk and dawn catch of adult mosquitoes was made in
all screened quarters in that section in order to destroy
infected mosquitoes, and as an index to the effectiveness of
the drainage work.

Very little oil was used in controlling breeding since the swamps
were too extensive and the cost would have been prohibitive. It would also
have been necessary to remove all vegetation before oiling, the cost of this
would have been very great, and the measure only temporarily efficacious.
The method used to control breeding was as follows: Trochas (paths six
6
feet wide) were cut through the swamp at 50-yard intervals. Sea-level
drains, varying in size according to carrying capacity required, were
dug along the center of the trochas; most of them were only eight inches
wide, i. e. “spade wide.” These drains were kept free from vegetation.

These control measures were very effective and the results were
more than gratifying. The adult anopheles catch in the camp was reduced
from a monthly catch of 3,700 in July to 1,100 in August and to 600 in
September, which was the lowest catch ever recorded for that season of
the year.

The malarial rate in July was the highest recorded since 1915.
The epidemic reached its height in that month when 67 cases were reported
among the 8,500 employees living in the Cristobal-Colon district. How-
67/88
ever, this rate was immediately reduced within one month, and in August
only 19 cases were reported, as compared with 21 for August, 1918. The
malarial rate has been very low since the termination of this epidemic.
The greatest number of cases reported in one month during 1920 was 15,
the greatest number reported in any one month during 1921 was 7, and in
1922, 12 cases. Therefore, the once seemingly impossible task of con-
trolling malaria in Cristobal-Colon has almost been accomplished.

Colon presented one of the most difficult problems of sanitation
on the entire Isthmus of Panama. The city was almost surrounded by exten-
sive swamps in which anophelines were breeding in countless millions. The
7
filling or drainage of these swamps would have necessitated an almost
prohibitive expense. One million dollars was, at one time, requested
for the filling of one of the swamps near the Army and Navy posts, but the
expenditure was not made and the swamp still exists, although breeding has
been successfully controlled therein by drainage. Since there were no
funds for the filling of these swamps, drainage was relied upon to solve the
problems. As the swamps were only from a few inches to two or three
feet above sea-level, large open sea-level canals with connecting laterals
forming a kind of checkerboard effect, were cut through the center of the
swamps. This was done for the purpose of draining off the fresh water ac-
cumulations and allowing salt water to circulate freely through the entire
system with each ebb and flow of the tide, and to admit top minnows to the
anopheles breeding areas. It was not necessary to oil these drains since
the salt water and minnows rendered them unfavorable for anopheles breeding.
This work was begun in 1917 and continued until 1922 when the various drain-
age systems were practically completed.

The cutting and removal of all vegetation inside the so-called sani-
tated zone was continued until 1919. In 1919 the cutting of grass and other
vegetation by the Health Department was discontinued except for the prevention
of mosquito breeding in wet areas until drains have been installed. The cut-
ting of vegetation for the purpose of eliminating mosquito harborage was not
considered as a justifiable routine measure, and was a useless expense which
not only did no good but diverted funds and effort from the more important
8
work of controlling mosquito breeding by drainage. The use of “spade-
wide” tide water drains for controlling anopheles breeding in swamps
near tide water has given excellent results. By the use of these drains
mosquito breeding is controlled over large areas at a minimum expense.

The administration of prophylactic doses of quinine (5 grains)
was a routine anti-malaria measure in Cristobal-Colon until 1918, when the
malarial rate reached such a low level that it was considered safe to dis-
continue this measure. However, during the 1919 epidemic at Camp Bierd
10 grains of quinine in liquid form was given each person in this camp
daily for three months.

The routine daily catching of adult anopheles in quarters was
discontinued on September 7, 1921, and at present only periodic catches
are made. The attached chart of the anopheles catch shows that it was
reduced to almost nil, even during the rainy season of 1921.

The mosquito control force for this district, which covers an
area of approximately 18 square miles and contains 55 miles of drains,
consists of one white sanitary inspector, one colored foreman and 23
colored laborers. Although this small force is about 50% less than the
mosquito control force of 1917, the sanitated area has been increased
more than four times the size it was in that year and breeding therein has been
successfully controlled. One of the laborers has been trained as an
anopheles larva hunter; he inspects all drains and fresh water accumu-
9
lations in the district once each week, taking a sample of any larvae
found, and if he finds any anopheles he reports it immediately so that
the oiling man may destroy the breeding at once.

list.item:
1. In order to successfully control malaria at Cristobal-Colon
it is first necessary to control mosquito breeding within mosquito flight
distance which at Cristobal-Colon may extend for at least two miles. The
installation of ditches which permit the free circulation of sea water is
an economical and efficient method of accomplishing this.

2. The elimination of mosquito harborage by cutting and removal
of vegetation is not now necessary since the most favorable harboring
place for adult mosquitoes is in and under houses. The great desideratum is
the elimination of mosquito breeding by methods which act continuously
and almost permanently.

3. The administration of sterilizing doses of quinine (10 grains)
every day for a period of twelve weeks is a useful adjuvant to anopheline
control during an epidemic, since it reduces the plasmodium index and the
opportunity for mosquito infection.
